name: pnp-sp-dev-spfx-sp-dev-fx-webparts-react-M365-planner-timeline
title: M365 Planner Timeline Web Part
shortDescription: The purpose of this web part sample is to render M365 Group Plan tasks in a timeline ordered by the task due date with tags for years and months in a vertical stack. There are filter options to filter out completed tasks and tender tasks by a plan bucket. A task's detail can be viewed by clicking the (i) icon below the "Due Date" popping up a callout dialog with task details. It Should be noted that a M365 Group Planner can have 0 to 200 plans assigned to M365 Group. The web part needs to be configured in the web part's property pane you must select the plan to be rendered, along with options for the plan bucket and completed task filter. These setting will be used when the web part renders on the page. The configuration of multiple web parts on the page for different plans and buckets is supported.
longDescription: The purpose of this web part sample is to render M365 Group Plan tasks in a timeline ordered by the task due date with tags for years and months in a vertical stack. There are filter options to filter out completed tasks and tender tasks by a plan bucket. A task's detail can be viewed by clicking the (i) icon below the "Due Date" popping up a callout dialog with task details. It Should be noted that a M365 Group Planner can have 0 to 200 plans assigned to M365 Group. The web part needs to be configured in the web part's property pane you must select the plan to be rendered, along with options for the plan bucket and completed task filter. These setting will be used when the web part renders on the page. The configuration of multiple web parts on the page for different plans and buckets is supported.

thumbnails.alt: Web Part to display a planner plan tasks in a vertical timeline.

references.name: Build your first SharePoint client-side web part
references.description: Client-side web parts are client-side components that run in the context of a SharePoint page. Client-side web parts can be deployed to SharePoint environments that support the SharePoint Framework. You can also use modern JavaScript web frameworks, tools, and libraries to build them.

references.name: Build custom controls for the property pane
references.description: if you need additional functionality beyond the basic controls. You might need asynchronous updates to the data on a control or a specific user interface. You can build a custom control for the property pane to get the functionality you need.

references.name: Use Microsoft Graph in your solution
references.description: Microsoft Graph provides a unified programmability model that you can use to build apps for organizations and consumers that interact with the data of millions of users. You can easily access Microsoft Graph also from SharePoint Framework solutions.
